evidence.text: Person B: -place is in complete disarray; a whole mess of books and paperwork so I guess we'd just like some tall shelves and cabinetry installed? Maybe make him a ladder with little wheels on it, you know, like you'd see in a real library? He's a voracious reader.
Person B: I'm thinking... Shelves up to the ceiling, and some good reading lamps. Perhaps some wall fixtures that extend? Father always keeps the curtains drawn.
Person A: -to protect the books from the sunlight. We are south-facing here.
Person B: Keep it below six or seven hundred dollars, can you? My sister and I are splitting it. I don't want any unexpected add-ons.
Person A: Just a moment please!
Person B: She doesn't speak English.

Person A: Oh, but you should. You should, you see. My father would like us to hire you.
Person A: That's why he's asked me to oversee and assist you in this endeavor.
Person A: Father described it as more of a reading room for the public...

Person A: It's ambitious. Thought you'd like that... I've put in a call to our frequent contractor, Leslie Woodrow. We first worked with Leslie as one of our Ship Engineering Officers but he's supervised several important construction projects for us since- including these offices. My father is allocating a sum of 850,000 dollars for this project which to me seems very reasonable, if not exorbitant. If Leslie agrees to come on-board, I'll have him start a budget for us right away.
Person B: Zs-ofia... Are you planning for school?

Person B: Yes.
Person A: Leslie mentioned during our meeting last week with Jim that you're putting your fee back into the project. That seems a bit irresponsible given your situation, doesn't it? Will it even last you to the end of your commitment?
Person A: Have you discussed it with your wife?
Person A: Suit yourself but I wouldn't do it, and I know Leslie certainly wouldn't do it, so I didn't want you to think you'd be setting any sort of precedent.
Person B: How does that work exactly? The company paying themselves to finance?
Person A: Do you not think I deserve to be paid for the time and energy I devote to this project?
Person A: Might I make a suggestion?
Person B: You may.
Person A: Your niece has made several of our guests very uncomfortable. Perhaps you should have a talk with her.
Person B: About what?
Person A: Don't get me wrong. She's very lovely to look at and as much as we all dream of having a bird that keeps her trap shut, it comes off like a rude affectation. I've tried to connect, make conversation. It goes nowhere.
Person A: Oh, I see. It must run in the family.
Person A: I would like us to be friends...
Person B: This is not- friendly, Harry.
Person A: We tolerate you.
